roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now on number oh one seven fourteen, Utah versus Donald L Evans, Secretary of Commerce.
Mr. Lee.
[Inaudible]
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
For most of the history of the census of the American population, that census has been conducted by means of an actual count unaltered by any methods of statistical estimation.

At the time of the first census of seventeen ninety, James Madison noted that this was the way required by the Constitution and ever since then, that requirement is employ- been implemented by Congress in the Census Act.

The question presented in this case is whether the Census Bureau acted unlawfully in departing from that longstanding historical tradition by using the method of estimation called hot-deck imputation in the two thousand apportionment count.
Ninety-nine point six percent of the two thousand apportionment count was comprised of actual data compiled by census enumerators in two phases.
First, a mailing sent to all addresses on a master address file, and second, as many as six follow-up visits.
Imputation added an additional point four percent to that count, one point two million statistically generated persons were added to the apportionment count by means of a statistical estimate.

Th- The basic essence of the estimate was to say the six hundred and twenty thousand addresses that the Census Bureau was unable to enumerate are assumed to have estimated to have the same number of occupants as their next door neighbor...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Lee, I I would like to ask you to address early on whether this injury that Utah alleges to have suffered is redressable in any fashion.
Things have happened since the census was taken.
North Carolina presumably has drawn districts and has gone quite far down the road in reliance on the census.
The President has turned over the numbers and so forth.
How can this be redressed, do you think, now?
I I suppose, Justice O'Connor, that there are two aspects of your question if I'm understanding it.
One of them would be a a redressability standing question.
That's a question as the Solicitor General notes that has already been decided by this Court both in Franklin and in Montana...
with regard to...
Well, there's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: jurisdiction, but I don't know that we have really addressed the redressability issue fully in prior cases.
It it would have been impossible, Justice O'Connor, for Utah to have brought a challenge prior to the census.
indicated...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: why is that? I mean, you knew, did you, that the Census Bureau planned to use it?
Yes.
knowledge.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: had an injury.
We wouldn't have had an injury, and in fact as the Census Bureau itself indicates, there would have been no way even to have anticipated that imputation would have had this...
effect.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you have no incentive to bring a challenge until you know that you are losing a congressional seat, I...
suppose.
That's exactly right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, was there a window of time between completion of the census and the the submission of the numbers to the President where you could have sued? How long was that period of time?

the that was , the the time line is that the Secretary must submit the numbers by the end of the calendar year to the President, and then the President must submit those numbers within seven days after the first day of of the Congress.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well well, if you prevail, what's what's supposed to happen?

The remedy that we're asking for, Justice Kennedy, is simply a declaration and an injunction to the Secretary of Commerce directing the Secretary to issue a new apportionment count free of the statistical estimates that we believe are unlawful under the Census Act and under the Census Clause of the Constitution.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what's su- supposed to happen under the Act? I mean, the act, I went back and read the Act last night.
And I think, Justice Souter, that's effectively North Carolina's argument.
token...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I I will presume that, too, but that was four justices, and there there wasn't a specific discussion of of what is supposed to happen under the statute, even assuming the President sort of takes counsel from our opinion.

And and the other opinion in that case, Justice Souter, that also addresses this issue was Justice Stevens' concurring opinion, for a separate four-justice concurrence on this issue, and his analysis was in fact that the statute would require the President to conform to a revised count that the Secretary might present in conformity to...
a decision of this Court.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He said and as you know, I I I joined his opinion.
Why...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: will they, I mean, it it's it seemed so to me at the time but it's a real issue in this case, as to whether the the statute which is which is geared to delivery of information at certain times can in effect reverse itself.

The other point that Justice Stevens made in his concurring opinion, Justice Souter, which I think is critical on this issue, is that the time deadlines under the statute can be understood only to trigger, o- o- only with regard to the issue of ripeness.
and hide the issue...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: tho- those are not cases where after, the after the deadline provisions, you have a, r- m- a a basic change in, in in in the court's role, that after the deadline in this case, you are going to have to, the court is going to have to issue an opinion that purports to bind the President.
Yeah.
point.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But I mean that's, that's even worse.
Well, the, the the order would go to the Secretary.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Lee, do...
Well what what if if I if I may...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: just a- what what's what's what's your closest case to show that a a declaration of this kind satisfies s- the requirement of redressability?
Well, I I believe it's Franklin, Justice Kennedy...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Par- excuse me.
Well the the...
the Franklin was...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: fractured opinion...
W- one understanding consistent with Justice O'Connor's opinion in Franklin would be that of a declaratory judgment.
Well, it it it it...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: does bind the parties in a certain extent.
That's right, Mr. Chief Justice, and I and I think that that's consistent again with with Justice O'Connor's plurality opinion in Franklin.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We've we've never held that a declaratory judgment will issue where the Court has no power to to compel the action that the that the declaratory judgment describes.
Well, Justice Scalia, but I think there are two alternative theories.
But the secretary might repres-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: also that whether or not the President would respond, at least the Secretary would have a have a duty to do something in response to our order.
That's exactly...
right, Justice Kennedy...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: common that in in suits the President is not named, and the Secretary is.

The final step, Justice Ginsburg, in this process, is for the clerk of the House of Representatives to forward to the states a certificate that shows how many seats in the House of Representatives they're entitled to after the clerk receives the revised numbers from the President.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You only have a certain amount of time, Mr. Lee.
Well, the the actual enumeration clause of the Constitution would require an actual count, and...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
Yes, they do, Mr. Chief Justice, and one of the reasons is that the mere fact that there are lights on and and cars there doesn't tell us that this is anyone's usual place of residence.
But do- but doesn't con-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It doesn't confirm it but i- is isn't it a permissible inference for the census takers?
Well, at some point a census taker may make a conclusion, if it's based on information specific to an individual household, may make a conclusion that a household is in fact occupied.
and that's what...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Would you, on that theory, would you agree that although they may not impute a number beyond one, it would be fair for them at leaf at least to count it as one? Because they start out as I understand it with a in affect a report from post office saying you know this is a house at which somebody lives.
Justice Souter, they they don't start out with a proposition that this is a house and somebody lives there.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, doesn't an an address usually mean somebody lives there, at least if we can establish that it's a residential neighborhood?
Not necessarily, for a number of reasons.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What percentage of homes in the United States when they take the census turn out to be vacation or second homes?
I I don't have that number handy off the top of my head, Justice O'Connor.
unrelated...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: e- techniques apparently treat all the dwellings that are identified as residences to be counted? They don't discount for a percentage that are vacation homes?
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That that's saying that they're doing it bad.
I think not.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, why not?
and they make an...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: assumption that if the pizza man delivers pizza to the place and people eat the pizza, IE at least it disappears, that there is someone in the house? Can they make that assumption?
The- they cannot, Justice...
Breyer. People...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the assumption about the pizza man.
No.
What...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: there's a sign in front that says this is not a vacation home.
Well then I suppose I suppose under those circumstances, then we'd have...
Fine. Once you're down that,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: once you're down that road, then you're then then I can easily construct examples where the imputation is absolutely as strong.
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You know have to take that position.
I I think it's important, though, to to answer your question, Justice Breyer, to to go back to the baseline of the House of Representatives decision.
here's why.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Are you suggesting, Mr. Lee, that the Census Bureau goes about this thing in in a way, s- say supposing you have a lake in northern Wisconsin where the temperatures get down to about forty below in the winter.

Well, i- if they know that there's somebody who's living there, they have to find out whether the somebody who's living there lives there as as his usual place of residence, or that person doesn't count in the apportionment count.
going...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: under the imputation method as I understand it, the assumption is made that if a house is there, that it is a residence, and a second assumption is made that the number of occupants will be that in in a general geographic area of other homes.
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm I'm I'm curious both in your argument here this morning and in the brief, I I think both parties seem to assume that the key question is whether or not this is sampling.
Our position is, Justice Kennedy, that any method that takes information from a part of the population to make an inference about the whole is a is a method of sampling and is prohibited.
example.

It it it's called the method of of quality assurance, and i- at the quality assurance phra- phase, what the Bureau does is to randomly send out enumerators to given census tracts to try to find the tracts where there are a large number of errors, where the enumerators may have made a lot of mistakes.
What a what a what a...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: about a house where they have not been able to find anybody to talk to, no returns sent back, so they go to the people next door and they say is there anybody living in that house and the person next door says yes, there are two people.
That is permissible under our theory.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But...
but...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but but the Act refers both to sampling and to other methods of statistical adjustment.
Well, there may be another way to to get there, Justice Kennedy, but my understanding under the statute is that Section one ninety-five prohibits the statistical method known as sampling.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
I- in fact, Justice Souter, that is not a distinction.
the House of Representatives case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: it it it wouldn't in a literal sense if you were simply making one imputation at a time, but you were making a long series of imputations from the one sample, in this case, the one house.

But Justice Souter, once you pool all of the individual housing units together, the six hundred and twenty th- seven six hundred and twenty thousand, rather, of these housing units that were used to estimate the six hundred and twenty thousand addresses that we know nothing about after six follow-up visits, that's your sample.
That's your group.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: isn't six hundred and twenty to tell you about just any random six hundred and twenty.
Mathematically it seems to me, though, Justice Souter, we get to the same end.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah, but that, I mean that would be true about any inferential conclusion.
It it is also true, however, Justice Souter, of the method struck down by this Court in the House of Representatives case.
Mr. Lee, go...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well Mr. Lee as I understand it, the imputation method that was actually used after the two thousand census has the effect of counting non-households as households in some instances.
That's correct, Justice O'Connor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it counts one household several times in some instances.
That's correct, because some of...
Yeah, all right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it's and the imputation is not based on the nearest neighbor.
Well, ordinarily, as I understand it, it is the nearest neighbor address that's used to estimate or impute the address about which we know nothing.
That's not...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's not my understanding, but we can explore that with the other side.
That's exactly right and and of course the scale of the practice is beside the point.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, it that they say it isn't beside the point.
Well, Justice Breyer, let me mention two reasons why that distinction doesn't get them anywhere.
All right we have the statistical definition...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but my question was directed at a particular problem that, if I take your approach I can't get myself out of.
The the problem with the distinction is, another problem with the distinction is that it's clear that it would permit the Census Bureau to replicate the nineteen ninety-seven plan.
I don't understand...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the the pizza man.
No, no it goes from the whole to the parts.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: it's it's not the same kind of inference that that is done by what yo- what by what you say is sampling mainly, im- im- imputing information that belongs to a part to the whole.
Yeah m- maybe, Justice Scalia and Justice Breyer, maybe I missed the pizza man example, but but that may well, the that may well be a a a distinction.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I didn't think the imputation involved any actual things like looking at, when pizza was delivered.
That's what's going on.
That's precisely right, Justice O'Connor.
ninety-seven.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Lee, didn't it prove out that, a- after, that in the majority of these cases, something like seventy-five percent, that th- they know for sure that these were houses where people lived?
A- Actually not, Justice Ginsburg.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you don't have a n- negative showing, either, that that it wasn't accurate? And it there was something Justice O'Connor said, and and I'm not sure that I fully understand it.
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Very well, Mr. Lee.

May it please the Court, because North Carolina believes s- very strongly that the right time to challenge the Census Bureau's planned use of a statistical method is before rather than after the census is completed, and let me begin...
by addressing...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: how could i- the challenge have been brought before Utah knew that the imputation figures caused this problem?
Under your decision in House of Representatives, I think on...
page...

three thirty-two, you note that citizens of Utah, you didn't specify the state, but citizens who anticipate that the use of a method like imputation, as suburbanites might, would dilute their intrastate districting representation, are specifically said in House of Representatives to have authority to bring that suit.
response to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you can't bring a suit before you know what what's going on.
Yes, you can, Mr. Chief Justice.
But Mr. Dellinger,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: a state can't, are you suggest there are suburban people, city people, a state can't, until it knows what the result is going to be, and Congress used the words any aggrieved person.
Justice Ginsburg, that is correct, if a state is unable to show, does not have the experts about a forthcoming census that is unable to demonstrate that it will be aggrieved.
But they are...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: aggrieved at the end of the line.
They are now, but my point is that if Utah had been watching this carefully, and as you know, many states were involved in the ninety-seven litigation as amici and otherwise.
But he had no incentive...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He had no incentive to do so.
I understand...
that, Jus-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: he could have gotten a s- a stalking horse to, some suburbanite to bring the suit but he had no no notion that it there was any reason to do that.

It seems to me that that is i- i- e- i- exactly correct, but that it's it's exactly why any governor, major city mayor or others, these citizens, that those who brought suit in nineteen ninety-seven and did not include this, i- suburbanites are going to hurt, would want to sue, could bring the suit, but in any event, they could also participate in the Bureau's process.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there a statutory time period for people to challenge the the Census Bureau proposed techniques before the census is taken? Is there some provision whereby that challenge can be made?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mhm.
and that suit allows aggrieved parties to bring suit when the census produces its plan.
certainly at least...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but i- is it a fact that somebody is aggrieved when you are at the stage of the Census Bureau just saying this is what I plan to do?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mhm...
that's exactly how it worked in House of Representatives, if you do that plan, we expect that our district will be diluted.
The...
the l-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: does the law provide for some sort of administrative hearing be- before the Census Bureau, some sort of an exhaustion requirement? I thought that's what you were suggesting.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Bu-
but you say...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: now the Bureau, i- i- i- is is that well publicized? Is there some person you can go to in the Bureau and say I don't like what youre doing?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Seems unfair to Utah, though, to say that they are supposed to bring a suit before they know they have been hurt and why.
Justice Breyer, those who sued in the House of Representatives litigation had a very thin basis for knowing that they would be adversely affected.
Well, of course,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: sometimes you could guess in advance, but a lot of times you couldn't, and it's important that there be a fair method that treats states fairly.
So why,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: why would it be fair, any way, to cut off those states that don't know they've been treated unfairly and hurt, until they find out later?
And here's why.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Bis- Mr. Dellinger, you have recognized that your argument is, a state in the position of Utah that can't project what the returns will be, does not have, does not qualify as an aggrieved person at the only moment in time when it can say that it it's aggrieved.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Are are you sure they were not aggrieved at the beginning? I'm I'm surprised that you I mean, i- is it not an aggrievement for the State of Utah or for any state that its districts are distorted? Even if it doesn't doesn't lose, you know, congressmen for to another state, isn't the distortion of the districts within that state b- a grievance of that state?
That is a very helpful answer, and that is not a very helpful suggestion.
court...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: before you go on to the merits, you have nothing else to say then about justiciability? I mean, let's suppose they can file a suit.
Wh- what's the remedy...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
